etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in John P. Kennedy (1795–1870), novelist and politician. Probably from an unattested Virginia Algonquian cognate of Meskwaki wâkihpeni and Ojibwa (Nipissing) waagipin, both denoting the same plant from a first element of uncertain origin + an Algonquian base denoting an edible root or tuber

definitions: A lotus native to North and Central America having fragrant yellowish-white flowers, large cupped leaves on long petioles, and edible seeds and tubers, Nelumbo lutea.
